reviews.review_text: I've been playing for 1.5 years now, ever since closed Alpha- I remember when it was just a small group of players trying to take down the Underground Base boss, repeatedly dying. When we finally did, it was the best thing ever- and that stands true to this day when it comes to bosses.   The game is permadeath, so when you die you lose everything. A lot is going on at all times, and no shell really has that much defense. Ironclad may have high health and defense, but it's slow and can't dodge well- you need skill for every single shell to stay alive. This makes every accomplishment all the better, compounded by the fact that Starbreak is a multiplayer game- you can share and brag about the things you've done~  I can't wait too see where this game goes, and I hope it survives. Hopefully we can still be playing years from now :3

StarBreak is a roguelike co-operative platformer that's centered around player progression.  When I say 'centered around player progression' I say it as opposed to classic in-game character progression, which is what MMO's and most games do these days.  StarBreak has permadeath. If you die with your character (your shell, as the game calls it), all his stuff is lost, he's gone forever (god bless his soul) and you win experience points that level up your Soul based on how far he got. Having a higher soul level lets you unlock the other characters that have completely different playstyles from the original one you get.  What a lot of people don't seem to understand is that the level progression is entirely artificial. They make you wait to play the other characters because they want to player to get more experienced with the game and enemies to be able to know how to react to different situations according to the unlocked character and it's difficulty.  This game has basically no progression other than the stash, because as mentioned before it's a game about player progression. Getting further and further into the game can only be done through first-hand experience with the enemies, which feel consistent and fair given how they're placed strategically on the terrain. This is basically how it goes, in order: 1.You'll get hit by stuff you see coming. 2.You'll get hit by stuff you saw coming, but couldnt manage to avoid it. 3.You'll get hit a lot by stuff you didn't know could do X in X way. 4.You'll die to situations you couldn't predict other than experiencing them.  Now, all of the above will gradually go away, until you can control your character consistenyl and be constantly aware of the environment, which feels extremely rewarding for the player, complemented by it's MMO aspect:  When racing through a difficult dungeon with others, most of the times only the experienced, skilled and thick-skinned players push on and advance. Not the ones that tediously grinded for days, built their character differently, or whatever the hell other games do: They got there because they faced the challenges and persevered, by dying to them previously over and over and over again.   There is a cash currency in the game, known as UC. With it, you can buy additional stashes and player slots, coupled with a few vanity hats on rotation.Additional stashes are useful if you're keeping the equipment for the next character, and the hats are lost on death too. What I would argue goes against the main point of the game, are the additional player slots. Having additional player slots means you get more loot efficiency than other players that don't, should you choose to play more characters at once. In a game about not dying and getting as far as possible, being able to change shells sort of kills the feeling of only having one life as, since there's no trading, you're essentially saving the equipment you can't use with the current shell, to yourself. Not your 'future' self, but your 'now' self. A possibility free players don't have.  It is however, not a game for everyone. It seems extremely unforgiving in certain aspects and I feel like having to explain the fun of the game to someone else defeats the purpose if the person itself didn't find it fun. Many don't like it for it's permadeath aspect, yet I feel like they're just missing the point entirely. While it is quite sad to lose all the progress in a simple mistake, a lot of the times, to me, felt justified. Be it a bit of bad luck, bad positioning or a tough enemy: whenever I was about to die, I could feel it in my veins that those were my last moments, and that was exactly how it was meant to be. The game is what it is. There's no point in trying to make it something that it is not. Removing permadeath would remove a lot of the tension which IMO is a huge part of StarBreak.  If you liked the early days megaman and metroid, you'll probably have a blast with this game. The multiplayer aspect works really well with it, more than i'd initially thought it would. Coupled with the permadeath, it's a game where while in lower levels you just shrug off character deaths, later on you really feel for them, and i've sacrificed myself more than once in hopeless boss fights to let the other players teleport back to base (takes like 10 seconds of standing still) by providing them with cover fire. As another review said: 'It felt like ♥♥♥♥ing Starship Troopers.'  Some more technical points: The gamepad feel is great. I used and Xbox controller for it and it's already binded, with some emotes custom-bound to the D-pad. What bothers me is the second character's (Duskwing) dash control, since for some reason the special dash is canceled if you let your movement stick go back to neutral position. It can be really ♥♥♥♥ing confusing to see her just stall after doing the dash because you moved your stick to the same direction she's going, but that's minor once you get used to it. (THIS ISSUE WAS FIXED A FEW DAYS AFTER THIS REVIEW, CHEERS DEVS)  Needless to say, it runs well. The graphics aren't intensive, keeping it in a stable 60 fps, and the design aesthetics never feel off from the visual pacing aswell. Sound wise, the effects have a pleasant hit-noise and the music's good. It's not that memorable, but it definitely sets the scene for each environment and scenario presented, enough to make cold-blooded people have a decent surge of adrenaline.  All in all, it's a great free to play time-killer and tons of fun for those that like the jump'n'shoot genre and/or want to fool around with friends. It may feel rewarding to beat enemies you previously died to whilst growing as a player yourself, but it's always more satisfying when you do it with other people.

I started playing the tutorial of this game, found out the controls, and was surprised to see that it is a keyboard-only-needed game, which sparked my interest. (I'm aware that there is controller support, haven't yet tried that out.)  It's a permadeath, looting, MMO, side-scrolling platformer game. Not a combination you see very often. Yet, somehow, it works very well.  Once I got used to the controls (which didn't take very long), I was instantly in love with this game. Everything is so smooth in gameplay, and it's so fun right from the beginning.  Then I got to what is basically a hub world, and I smiled. Oh, I smiled.  What makes me so happy with this game is that it's a free-to-play game that doesn't shove paid currency stores and pay-to-win nonsense down your throat. It's very wonderful to play just as a player who doesn't invest amy money into it. Sure, you can spend real money to get extra item storage and customisation items, but to be honest, you don't really need them.  The community is awesome, in the sense that when you're in an area and there are a few people around you, you will all start sub-consciously helping each other and not knowing it. And trust me, it helps when you come to area bosses.  I probably haven't explained the game much, but believe me when I say that this is definitely a game worth trying. It's free, what have you got to lose? (Well, apart from hours of your time into this game...)  Would fully recommend.

Before I begin: Don't go down-voting this review because you hate seeing your favorite game getting criticism. Instead, actually read through this review, and take into consideration the things I have to say, as much of what is here could be considered a legitimate reason for viewing a game so negatively. Many issues I will be pointing out here have also been pointed out by not just myself, but others on both sides of the 'aisle'. All I ask is that you allow a guy a moment to offer his opinion.   Seeing as I apparently earned the ire of a few people for being 'negative about a perfect game', I'm rewriting this review to give more people insight into why I cannot recommend this game. I even TRIED to enjoy it, TRIED to play it and see the good in it, even after writing this the first time. As you can plainly see: Not much has changed, and I've only come away from it with more to focus on.  First of all: I still stand by the feeling that this has the 'potential' to be a great game with some pretty interesting mechanics. However, the mechanics are also what make this such a difficult game for me (and others) to like and enjoy. The gameplay is fun when you're on a roll, when you're blasting through enemy after enemy, finding really good gear to use, and just nailing those difficult jumps and attacks when it really matters. But the progression and combat mechanics can also make all of that work you've put into leveling damn-near useless, no matter how good you get.  When you die, you lose everything, including gear and stats. When you enter a new shell, you start back at square 1: bare bones stats, the most basic of weapons, no body or mobility gear, and not one thing to show for the amount of work you put into playing, except for a little pocket change and a tiny handful of experience points. Even then, it's not worth the trouble, as money is currently useless, and your level only dictates which shells you can use.  When out on the field, you pick up stat boosts to enhance your shell's abilities, which is all fine and dandy, as a couple extra HP can mean the difference between life and death. As you collect these stats, you will sometimes find that you max out an ability. This means that you've just maxed out one ability needed for the increase of your shell's MK level! Awesome! But, like I said: You die, you lose it all, and you have to do it all again. The only way to keep those stats is to stay alive through the entire dungeon. What doesn't help is that you have to collect MK II upgrades from harder dungeons, which means...You guessed it. You're gonna lose all that work, and lose that shiny MK II rating. It's not fun, it's not an enjoyable feature, and the only players who claim to see this as enjoyable are the 'hardcore' players, or those who believe the risk-reward system is 'perfect'. Not everyone is a masochist.  If you want to save those stats, plus the gear you managed to scrape up off the ground in a dungeon, you have the choice to purchase the game's premium currency, which can then be used to unlock a shell storage container, allowing you to switch out to another shell when you want to. Buying the currency is the only way to get these handy dandy containers, as, even if you were given the option, you'll almost never be likely to have the cash on-hand to pay for it, seeing as dungeons pay you in literal pocket change.  Oh yeah, you can even buy cosmetics with that same premium currency! But, like every other item in the game, it can be rendered useless, not to mention non-existent, the moment you die. In other words, you're wasting your time and money on something that doesn't even help you. People say it only costs you a few cents, but the amount really starts to add up, as you grab those same items and try a dungeon again. And again. And again. And again. It starts to add up very quickly.  You may be wondering, though: 'Just how easy would it be to die in this game? It all looks easy!'  Trust me. You'll die easily. SO easily, in fact, that you can likely attribute your death to either sluggish framerate, poor terrain generation, enemy placement, or a ridiculous combo of any and all of those things. Or you can attribute it to the often-insane number of players on-screen, which makes jumping and fighting nearly impossible in some situations, and it limits the amount of points you get when you die. Of course, you COULD run a dungeon solo. Wait wherever you spawned in at, give everyone a few minutes to die off or move on, and then you have all of those respawned monsters and a few treasures waiting for you. Just don't expect it to amount to much.  Not only will you be fighting a ton of alien creatures looking to strip away all of those shiny boosts and pieces of gear you've picked up, you'll be fighting the controls as well. If you're using a controller, aiming is VERY clunky, not to mention very frustrating, as it's tied directly to your movement stick (left stick by default, or d-pad). You can only fire left or right, and then diagonally in between those directions. That's it. No shooting straight up or down. There's no precision shooting, and there's little garuntee you'll hit that enemy coming at you at an odd angle, as you have to find that sweet spot to make your shell fire in an upward direction. Controller users also have to wrestle with the VERY unusual right-stick special. Flick your right analog stick up, down, left or right, and you fire off a special skill. It's a pain trying to use that in the middle of a boss battle, especially when you try to quickly go back to your default primary and secondary fire buttons (B and X on Xbox controllers), and more so when you're trying to out-manuever both the boss AND it's minions (wo spawn in so frequently that you'll likely die in a pit of the blasted things).  If you enjoy platforming games, or maybe just enjoy being put through hell for a handful of XP and credits that will do you very little, sure, this game is fun. But for others, myself included, this game just isn't fun. Fighting controls, fighting framerate issues, fighting BS terrain generation and enemy spawning, fighting the game's mechanics...None of that is fun, nor is it worth spending time trying to adjust to it.  And there you have it. My reasons for not enjoying this game, and for not recommending it.

Starbreak is a permadeath platformer mmo developed and released by Crunchy Games. It is a fast paced, metroidvania style mmo with both unique and familiar features.  PROS: -Fast paced combat. -Nice level variety. -Great art and beautiful soundtrack. -Challenging gameplay with a lare skill ceiling. -4 classes with nice variety and gameplay differences. -Very addicting. -All the loot you see is yours, you don't have to worry about stealing other peoples loot and vice versa. -Fun and challenging bosses that are all unique. - Not pay to win  CONS: -The RNG can sometimes screw you over. Like beating a boss and getting no weapons for your class, or getting weapons with bad modifiers. -Visual clutter, other players can obscure projectiles, leading to some cheap shots. -Instakill traps in a permadeath game, some levels have instakill mechanics, need I say more ? -The community, about 50/50 on this one, some people are really nice and helpful, but some can be as toxic as hell. -Some sounds can feel out of place, like the health pickup noise sounding like instant messaging, as well as massive earrape from lare amounts of players hitting the same enemy.   Overall, I do reccomend you pick up this game, its free, its non intensive on hardware, and its a good time for fans of platformers, roguelikes, or mmos in general.

Starbreak is a fantastic game, but it is lacking in many areas.   I'll start with a run-down of the good: -Fantastic Music and sound design that draws the player into the atmosphere -A breath of fresh air to the mmo genre and it changes the typical formula in many ways -An amazing art style that complements the game  Now, for the negative.   All of the negative problems stem from one thing: Microtransactions. The perma-death option is fantastic, but because you lose everything on death, that means you'll need to grab your spares from your stash or go back through the game to get new equipment. However, there is a lack of storage space, which can only be purchased through currency that must be purchased with real money. Similarly, since there are different characters(or 'Shells') in the game, you're going to need a LOT of storage to keep items for your previous character, and for your new one. Even if you start using a new shell, I would suggest keeping all the items from your previous one in storage in case you don't like your new shell. All these problems could be fixed with one of two things; either use the in-game currency as a way to purchase storage, or make goals to achieve in order to GAIN the purchasable currency. Also, there's barely any explanation on how to do anything or what everything is or is used for. The tutorial is great for introducing the mechanics, but not for anything else.  StarBreak is an incredible experience, even if it is flawed, but I'm not sure I would pin this ENTIRELY as 'pay-to-win.' More like, this is half pay to win, half traditional, and depending on which side you're on, you may or may not enjoy this game.   I like the idea of this game, and I look forward to seeing how this will be refined.

It's like Realm of the mad god, starbound, and contra had a baby. I love it.  Changing a bit of my review simply because of one reason, literally every single negative review here states that 'When you die, you lose everything! This is a bad choice.' No it's not, this is a roguelike. This is what happens, it's a design choice, if you don't like it it isn't your kind of game and I respect your opinion.  I also saw a few that say the devs are money hungry because you can spend money to buy extra space to store items? Yeah uh, you can literally do that in most MMO's, this isn't anything new. I'm a complete F2P user and I found that I don't really need anymore space than 6 slots, I don't pick up every single item I see, only the ones that I think I will need. For example, I ALWAYS keep an extra rifle for Wildfire (The first shell in the game) inside of the chest, because the starting shotgun is REALLY bad.  The only real flaws people are pointing out are ones that are design choices, they aren't flaws at that point, that just means you should play a different game. There are PLENTY of flaws with this game, which I have yet to see pointed out in the review section. For example, there's a limited social aspect to the game, which is really bad, as the game requires you to work with your team to take down bosses. That's a legit criticism and the devs have acknowledged this.  Sorry for the little rant, just gonna ignore this review now and go back to playing.

This game is difficult, and not in the 'oh my god, Dark Souls so hard' way but in an actual NES design era type game design. Every encounter and enemy in the game scales on the number of people who are with you, so if you are alone encounters are not as strong, but if you're in a big group then you basically need each other. It's not an unusual thing, of course, Phantasy Star Online used such a design to make grouping more rewarding but more difficult as well, and there's nothing wrong with that.  When the player dies, they lose everything they have equipped and are carrying, with no way to recover those items. To change character you also need to become a spark, which requires either EC (in-game currency), or to die. It's very easy to die, and you're basically expected to repeat the first dungeon over and over and over and over until you're either sufficiently leveled up to play as the character you actually want to play; or you basically outlevel the current content you're doing.  The game is a grindfest. As you play you will find minibosses, midbosses and bosses as well as enemies. Only midbosses and bosses are GUARANTEED to drop loot, but you'll definitely get plenty of chests along the way. As a diversion, I would say that the game is definitely a pretty good time sink, you'll keep playing, getting better little by little but also dying a lot.  Now for the negative, the in-game currency is tied to every type of purchase in the game, and there's two ways to acquire currency. Either you keep playing through dungeons -OR- you pay real money. Currency is NOT plentiful in dungeons, so I could see a lot of people opting for the microtransaction method of getting money, which I don't personally feel is worth the money but that's your choice not mine.  I'd give it a 7.5 out of 11, it can be a good time sink, but it sure can get old quick too.
